title: Aliciella penstemonoides
text:
Aliciella penstemonoides (<a href="Synonym%20%28taxonomy%29">syn.</a> "Gilia penstemonoides") is a species of flowering plant in the <a href="Polemoniaceae">phlox family</a> known by the common names Black Canyon gilia and beardtongue gilia. It is <a href="endemism">endemic</a> to <a href="Colorado">Colorado</a> in the United States.
This species is a perennial herb with stems growing up to 15 centimeters tall. There is a rosette of leaves around the base of the plant. The leaves are linear to lance-shaped and measure up to 5 centimeters in length. They are sometimes lobed. Smaller, narrow leaves occur higher on the stem. The branching <a href="inflorescence">inflorescence</a> contains purple, blue, or nearly white flowers, each about a centimeter long.
This species is distributed throughout five Colorado counties, with the center of distribution in <a href="Black%20Canyon%20of%20the%20Gunnison%20National%20Park">Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Park</a> and along the <a href="Gunnison%20River">Gunnison River</a>. There are about 28 occurrences. Fourteen are on <a href="National%20Park%20Service">National Park Service</a> lands, eight are on <a href="United%20States%20Forest%20Service">United States Forest Service</a> lands, and five are on <a href="Bureau%20of%20Land%20Management">Bureau of Land Management</a> lands. Only one is on privately owned land.
This plant grows on steep to vertical cliffsides in river canyons. It anchors in rock cracks. It grows at up to 10,000 feet in <a href="elevation">elevation</a>. Other plants on the canyon walls include "<a href="Arabis%20crandallii">Arabis crandallii</a>", "<a href="Arenaria%20fendleri">Arenaria fendleri</a>", "<a href="Artemisia%20frigida">Artemisia frigida</a>", "<a href="Artemisia%20ludoviciana">Artemisia ludoviciana</a>", "<a href="Heterotheca%20horrida">Heterotheca horrida</a>", "<a href="Heterotheca%20villosa">Heterotheca villosa</a>", "<a href="Holodiscus%20dumosus">Holodiscus dumosus</a>", "<a href="Oryzopsis%20micrantha">Oryzopsis micrantha</a>", "<a href="Ribes%20cereum">Ribes cereum</a>", and "<a href="Selaginella%20densa">Selaginella densa</a>". There are <a href="fern">fern</a>s, <a href="moss">moss</a>es, and <a href="lichen">lichen</a>s in some areas.
The threats to this species are not well known. Some occurrences are safe from most types of human interference because they grow on inaccessible cliff faces. Several occurrences are located near recreational areas used for hiking, fishing, and <a href="rock%20climbing">rock climbing</a>. Two occurrences were <a href="local%20extinction">extirpated</a> when the <a href="Blue%20Mesa%20Reservoir">Blue Mesa Reservoir</a> was created.
